posts.name: Scott Rowe, 3512
posts.cooked: Received our 2nd router and appears perfectly functional.  However, while cutting 26" tube to length, we verified the length on 2 separate mills to be 45 thousands too short.  Our zeroing methodology on the CNC is sound.  Is this out of tolerance?  Is there a calibration method on the CNC?  Is this too much out of spec?  Thanks.  Scott R. Team 3512

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
.045’’ is a pretty substantial error; usually the Omio can hold .005’’ pretty easily (better, if you’re slow and careful).

Make sure you’re not running a feed rate that’s causing your bit to deflect.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Scott Rowe, 3512
posts.cooked: Pretty slow feed rate.  The first thing we do after squaring an end on the mill is cut to length, so not sure how feed rate plays a role.  All we are doing after that is putting rivet holes space 0.5" apart but noticed that the the holes on the end were not what they needed to be which led us to a length issue.  Not sure what to do.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: First thing to do is verify that the machine is moving the correct distance, without cutting anything.

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked: (12 inch calipers are your friend here)

posts.name: Scott Rowe, 3512
posts.cooked: I thought I did that by cutting the end off at 26" with the CNC and verifying the length with 2 separate mills.  I could potentially cut a 26 inch piece on the mill, put it on the CNC, zero everything, and travel 26 inches down the length to see if it is off.  Unless there is a calibrated long precision cut piece of steel I can buy.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
sandarowe:

I could potentially cut a 26 inch piece on the mill, put it on the CNC, zero everything, and travel 26 inches down the length to see if it is off.

This is exactly what I’d do.

posts.name: Scott Rowe, 3512
posts.cooked: Cool, thanks.  Will post the results on Thursday.

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: Check to make sure the couplers are fully tightened. They’ve loosened on me in the past and I’ve lost motion during acceleration.

posts.name: Scott Rowe, 3512
posts.cooked: Thanks!  Now I just need to know how to identify the couplers you are talking about.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
They are attached to the stepper motor shafts and have set screws.

If you find that the error is constant across many lengths, it could be an endmill problem too.

posts.name: Scott Rowe, 3512
posts.cooked:
Cool.

Cut a 26" piece on the endmill (confirm with second mill) transfer to CNC, zero, and see what length the CNC is seeing.

Assuming off, tighten couplers and re-measure.  If by magic measurement is good, go to 3.  If still off, curl up in a fetal position.

If measurements are good, make sure to use a brand new endmill.

posts.name: Devin Castellucci
posts.cooked: The Mach 3 controller has settings that can be adjusted to correct for travel error, but you should only do this if you have tried everything else. Basically it does the math where X number of rotations = Y amount of travel distance. So if all else fails you can force it to move a correct distance.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: New endmill may not help, sometimes routers deflect when cutting. Taking extra finishing passes can help, but most often I find I just need to compensate for the tool diameter in CAM.

posts.name: Scott Rowe, 3512
posts.cooked: I haven’t thoroughly reviewed the CAM (students did the CAM, relatively easy part).  Maybe that should be first on my list.

posts.name: Dan_Karol
posts.cooked:
Not from an OMIO machine, but the designs are similar.

We had an issue were our spindle bracket loosened up just a touch.  That resulted in low tolerances but nothing else out of whack.  We measured the moves of the gantry and found they where dead-nuts on.

posts.name: Devin Castellucci
posts.cooked: Yes. Never trust the work of the guy before you, especially if that person was you. There are a number of times where had I listened to that advice I would have rechecked my work and saved myself a LOT of time.

posts.name: Nicholas Dal Porto
posts.cooked: We had this issue on 5940 back in 2018. Tightened up the couplers (like, a LOT) and that fixed it.
